Description: nuclear receptor subfamily 0, group B, member 1
Reviewer Commments: NR0B1 and NR0B2 when analyzed by NCBI's "Conserved Domain" tool show only the HOLI domain (Ligand binding domain of hormone receptors [smart00430]). HMMER hmmpfam analysis of human NR0B1 with the Pfam database shows PF00104.17 (Ligand-binding domain of nuclear hormone) as the top hit with a E-value of 4.3e-28, and PF02037.14 (SAP domain) as a distant second with and E-value of 0.00041. The SAP (after SAF-A/B, Acinus and PIAS) motif is a putative DNA binding domain found in diverse nuclear proteins. The NCBI GEnRIF for human NR0B1 states "This gene encodes a protein that contains a DNA-binding domain", while the entry for human NR0B2 states "The protein encoded by this gene is an unusual orphan receptor that contains a putative ligand-binding domain but lacks a conventional DNA-binding domain". Indeed, the canonical length of human NR0B1 is 470 AA, while the canonical length of human NR0B2 is 257 AA, consistent with the presence an extra domain (e.g., DNA binding) in NR0B1. HMMER hmmpfam analysis of human NR0B2 with the Pfam database shows PF00104.17 (Ligand-binding domain of nuclear hormone) as the top hit with a E-value of  6.9e-32, and PF03681.4 (Uncharacterised protein family) as a distant second with and E-value of 0.0022. Together, these considerations suggest that NR0B1 is a DNA-binding TF, and NR0B2 does not bind DNA, and is rather a co-factor.

Reviewer Commments: C/EBPs are a group of basic leucine zipper transcription factors identified by their sequence-specific binding to the CCAAT motifs in DNA. There are six different C/EBP family members that have been cloned and characterized. All members share homology at the bZIP domain and are multifunctional proteins that exhibit a diverse set of cellular responses like differentiation, inflammatory response, liver regeneration, metabolism etc. The target genes of the C/EBP family members are diverse and various studies have shown that C/EBP can modulate the expression of various matrix genes critical for osteoblast differentiation such as pro-{alpha}1 and -{alpha}2 type I collagen, matrix Gla protein, and osteocalcin. In most cases C/EBP{beta} can form a homodimer and bind to its recognition sequence; however C/EBP{beta} can also intraheterodimerize with other members of the family as well as with a variety of bZIP proteins such as CREB, C/ATF, and AP1. C/EBP{beta} has two major isoforms, liver-enriched activator protein (LAP), which is normally reported to be an activator and liver-enriched inhibitory protein (LIP), which lacks most of the trans -activation domain of LAP and thus acts as a dominant-negative inhibitor. Thus, C/EBP{beta} can directly activate or inhibit target gene expression.

Reviewer Commments: Fra-1 is one component of the AP-1 transcription factor, which consists of a complex mixture of polypeptides that are encoded by the immediate-early genes of the fos and jun families. Thethree Jun proteins (c-Jun, JunB, and JunD) and the four Fos family members (c-Fos, FosB, Fra-1, and Fra-2) share a homologous region containing the basic DNA-binding domain and the leucine zipper dimerization motif. Jun proteins are able to form homo- and heterodimers, while Fos proteins are only capable of forming heterodimeric complexes with Jun proteins. Both Jun and Fos contribute to the transactivation function of the AP-1 complex, which stimulates transcriptionby binding to AP-1 consensus sequences (TGA G/C TCA) in enhancer and promoter regions. There is conflicting evidence regarding Fra-1's transactivation function. DNA binding has been demonstrated via EMSA.
Fra-2 is reported in many AP-1 complexes. It binds to AP-1 specific binding site as a dimer and transactivate the transcription of ts targets.

Reviewer Commments: DTX1 negatively regulates the transcription of downstream targets likely in association with other cofactors. The cloned and affinity purified Gata1 proteins displayed similar DNA-binding properties in gel shift assays and DNase I footprinting studies.Gata1 transactivates the murine erythropoietin gene promoter (bases -1708 to -38) in transient transfections of COS-7 cells. Gata-2 is a transcription factor. It binds both ICAM-2 and MMP-2 promoter DNA sequences by EMSA/supershift assays and transfactivates the ICAM-2 promoter- and MMP-2-promoter reporter genes.
DNASe footprinting and gel shift assays indicate GATA-3 binds promoter regions. Cotransfection of human GATA-3 results in stimulation of HIV-1 LTR transcription.

TAGA-5 is a transcription factor. It demonstrates DNA-binding through supershifts and transactivates lactase-phlorizin hydrolase (LPH) promoter- and beta-MHC promoter- reporter genes.

Reviewer Commments: Gcn5l2 is an adaptor protein with histone acetyl transferase (HAT) activity, which is recruited by protein intermediates to other co-factors in order to regulate transcription. Rather, TRRAP likely recruits Gcn5l2 to c-myc, given that TRRAP co-immunoprecipitates with both Gcn5l2 and c-myc. As well, cotransfection of Gcn5l2 and a reporter vector into HeLa cells leads to increased reporter gene expression relative to reporter vector alone.

GLI1 activates a synthetic promoter containing 12 copies of the GLI response element following transient transfection in C3H10T1/2 cells. GLI1 also activates the PTCH1 gene promoter in C3H10T1/2 and NIH3T3 cells.

From human EntrezGene: "This gene encodes a protein which belongs to the C2H2-type zinc finger protein subclass of the Gli family. Members of this subclass are characterized as transcription factors which bind DNA through zinc finger motifs. These motifs contain conserved H-C links. Gli family zinc finger proteins are mediators of Sonic hedgehog (Shh) signaling and they are implicated as potent oncogenes in the embryonal carcinoma cell. The protein encoded by this gene localizes to the cytoplasm and activates patched Drosophila homolog (PTCH) gene expression."From OMIM: "Sequencing of GLI cDNA clones showed the presence of 5 tandem zinc fingers connected by histidine-cysteine links, which indicated that the gene belongs to the family of zinc finger genes related to Kruppel (Kr). The Drosophila gene Kr is a member of the gap class of segmentation genes; thoracic and anterior abdominal segments fail to form in Kr mutant embryos. This suggested to Ruppert et al. (1988) that other genes of this class might prove important in normal or disease states. Indeed, other genes important in neoplasia, such as NMYC (164840), LMYC (164850), HER2 (164870), and NRAS (164790), have been identified partly by their homology to previously identified oncogenes. Therefore, Ruppert et al. (1988) used a GLI cDNA fragment encoding the zinc finger region to isolate related human sequences. Six distinct loci were identified in this manner. "

From OMIM: "The forkhead genes are transcription factors distinguished by a characteristic 100-amino acid motif that was originally identified in Drosophila (see 164874). Pierrou et al. (1994) identified 7 human genes containing a forkhead domain and designated them forkhead related activators (FREAC) 1 through 7. Northern blot analysis revealed that the FREAC4, or FKHL8, gene is expressed as a 2.1-kb mRNA exclusively in testis and kidney. Pierrou et al. (1994) determined the DNA binding specificity of FKHL8 through selection of high affinity binding sites from random sequence oligonucleotides. Ernstsson et al. (1996) identified the human forkhead gene FREAC4 (FKHL8) as a nearly full-length cDNA and a 5.2-kb genomic fragment. The intronless gene predicts a protein of 465 amino acids with a hyperacidic N-terminal end, a DNA-binding forkhead domain, and a proline- and alanine-rich C-terminal end. The putative promoter region was active as a reporter fusion in the kidney-derived cell lines 293 and COS-7. Cotransfections with plasmids expressing WT1 (607102), WTAR (a mutated form of WT1), p53 (191170), and a mutated form of p53 revealed a complex pattern of regulation, suggesting that FREAC4 may be regulated by these gene products."

This transcription factor has both a DNA binding - sequence specific activity and a transcription regulation activity by interacting with Histones. The hepatocyte nuclear factors are transcriptional activators for liver-specific transcripts such as albumin and transthyretin. The HNF3 family, including HNF3A, HNF3B, and HNF3G are members of the forkhead class of DNA-binding proteins.The transcription factors Hnf3a and Gata4 are the earliest known to bind the albumin gene enhancer in liver precursor cells in mouse embryos. To determine how they access sites in silent chromatin, Cirillo et al. (2002) assembled nucleosome arrays containing albumin enhancer sequences and compacted them with linker histone. Hnf3a and Gata4, but not human NF1, mouse Cebp-beta, or yeast GAL4-AH, bound their sites in compacted chromatin and opened the local nucleosomal domain in the absence of ATP-dependent enzymes. The authors showed that the ability of Hnf3a to open chromatin is mediated by a high-affinity DNA-binding site and by the C-terminal domain of the protein, which binds histones H3 and H4. They concluded that factors that potentiate transcription in development are inherently capable of initiating chromatin opening events.

Gel shift studies also demonstrated that Hnrpab bound single-stranded DNA and RNA.Hnrpab repressed a promoter containing regulatory regions from the smooth muscle alpha-actin (pHASMA123CAT) gene following transient cotransfection in C2 cells.Hnrpab has a clearly identified role in regulating RNA splicing. It's role in transcription is less well-established and is usually not based on transient transfection studies (which may have difficulty distinguishing its effects on transcription and splicing). LIM factor Lhx3 is an Homeodomain transcription factor. Transcriptional regulation by LHX3 is complex, involving DNA binding-dependent actions mediated by the HD and transcriptional activation mediated by a major activation domain located in the carboxyl terminus and weaker activation functions in other domains. In experiments using pituitary hormone reporter genes, LHX3 has been demonstrated to function both alone and in synergy with other transcription factors, such as PIT1. In addition, in the developing nervous system, LHX3 is proposed to participate in gene regulatory complexes that include other LIM-HD proteins, such as islet 1 (ISL1), and LIM-interacting partners, such as nuclear LIM interactor (NLI)/cofactor of LIM proteins (CLIM).

FOXC1 binds to the FOX binding site and is capable of transactivation.
MITF binds and transactivates various promoters. It was demonstrated with a broad range of experiments.

Mnt is a transcription factor. It self homodimerizes and heterodimerizes with Max by EMSA, two-hybrid, and co-immunopreciptation assays and the Mnt/Max complex binds specific DNA sequences by EMSA and competition binding. Rox activates an artificial reporter construct in human cells.
MRG1 binds to and activates at least a dopamine receptor gene.

Reviewer Commments: MSX2 suppresses transcription via the OC promoter as shown by luciferase assay. Gel shift assays and ChIP assays indicate MyoD binds specific sites in the myostatin gene upstream region. Cotransfection experiments indicate MyoD preferentially up-regulates myostatin promoter activity.

Myogenin belongs to the myogenic regulatory factors (MRFs), a part of a superfamily of basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factors. The MRF proteins contain a conserved basic DNA-binding domain essential for sequence-specific DNA binding and a helix-loop-helix motif required for heterodimerization. Each of the MRFs has been shown to heterodimerize in vitro and in vivo with E proteins and to bind DNA in a sequence-specific manner at sites known as E-boxes (CANNTG). This DNA motif is present in the promoters of many skeletal muscle-specific genes and mediates gene activation in an MRF-dependent manner. Several studies have identified specific enhancer elements for MyoD and myogenin. Induction of the myogenin gene has been shown to be dependent on an E-box and a myocyte enhancer factor-2 element for proper expression in the somites and limbs of the developing mouse, suggesting that its expression is MRF-dependent, in part.
Myt1 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA (by selection/amplification experiments and DNase footprinting) and transactivates an HMyT1 promoter-reporter gene.

The myelin transcription factor 1 (Myt1) family represents neural zinc finger proteins of a structurally novel CCHHC class that were originally cloned by their binding to the promoter of the most abundantly expressed myelin gene, proteolipid protein. The consensus DNA-binding domain of the Myt1 family is Cys-X4-Cys-X4-His-X7-His-X5-Cys (also termed CCHHC domains).  Myt1-Like (Myt1L/neural zinc finger(NZF)-1/Png-1) has been shown to bind to DNA is a sequence-specific manner by competitive EMSA. Transactivation has also been shown by luciferase reporter assays.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Co-immunoprecipitation with AR, nuclear localization, and transcriptional effects make this gene most likely a co-factor.

Neurod1 interacts with an E box in the STF1 pancreatic islet-specific enhancer in gel shift assays performed using nuclear extracts from HIT-T15 cells. Cotransfected Neurod1 and E47 activate a reporter controlled by a minimal STF1 islet enhancer (bases -6200 to -5700) following transient transfection in HeLa cells.Neurod1 acting as a heterodimer with other bHLH factors, induces transcription from a reporter controlled by the proopiomelanocortin (POMC) gene promoter (bases -480 to +63). Gel shift assays, performed using nuclear extracts from transfected L cells and untransfected At-T20 cells, demonstrated that Neurod1 interacted with probes derived from POMC E-box sequences. Participation of Neurod1 in the retarded complex, for both At-T20 and transfected L cells, was confirmed by antibody supershift.

NDRF, in combination with E47, has been shown to activate IP3R1 gene expression via E-box motifs present in the box-I enhancer (EMSA and luciferase reporters). The C-terminal domain of NDRF is the activation domain, as demonstrated by deletion analysis and luciferase reporter gene experiments.

GeneID: 18019Referring to PMID: 15684054NFATc2 may be a transcription factor, which stimulates IL-21 promoter activity, and binds to the IL-21 proximal promoter. In unstimulated and PMA+I stimulated mouse EL4 cell lines, expression of a IL-21 promoter-reporter construct increases 40-fold and 600-fold respectively when cotransfected with NFATc2. Also, NFATc2 interacts with the IL-21 promoter in Th2 cells but not Th1 cells as demonstrated by ChIP. However, the specific binding site for NFATc2 within the IL-21 promoter still needs to be determined, and this is important information with regards to identifying NFATc2 as a transcription factor.

NFATc3 activates NFAT DNA site-dependent transcription in Jurkat cells. NFATc3 is modified by agents that increase intracellular calcium or activate protein kinase C.
Nfatc3 is a transcription factor.  It binds to DNA in electrophoretic mobility shift assays. It activates transcription from a reporter construct in transient transfections of MLE-15 cells.

As well, as demonstrated in PMID 7650004, NFATc3 activates mouse Sfptd promoter activity. Cotransfection of NFATc3 expression plasmids with Sftpd promoter-luciferase construct plasmids leads to increases in promoter activity.

The eukaryotic transcription factor NF-Y (also termed CBF) specifically recognizes the regulatory CCAAT element found in either orientation in the proximal and distal enhancer regions of many genes. Ovol1 is a member of a family of C2H2 zinc finger transcription factors that are part of the Wnt/β-catenin and TGF-β pathways.A CAST (cyclic amplification of selected targets) experiment performed with bacterially expressed Ovol1 identified a consensus DNA binding site 5'-A/TA/TA/TCC/TGTTAA/T-3'. Pax2 has been shown to bind to the promoter regions of several genes, including GDNF and SFRP2, and activate transcription.  Pax2 activation can further be enhanced by phosphorylation, as shown by CAT reporter assays. Specific DNA-binding has been shown by EMSA.

Pax6 encodes a protein that contains a Pax domain as well as the typical associated homeodomain.  Quail Pax6 binds core Pax sites identified in drosophila (PMID: 7841787) and a longer consensus site for human Pax6 was identified by in vitro selection (PMID: 8132558) consistent with sequence-specific DNA-binding.  Pax6 has been reported as both an activator (e.g. PMID: 7753864) and repressor (PMID: 9710641) in reporter cotransfection assays.
EMSA indicates Pax6 specifically binds the the A5 sequence in the MITF-A promoter. Luciferase assay in co-transfected Cos-7 cells shows Pax6 activates the MITF-A promoter.

Reviewer Commments: Pax7 was originally described as a member of the paired-homeobox gene family. It has been shown that the function of Pax7 partially overlaps with the paralogous Pax3 gene during development, which might explain the lack of a discernable phenotype in Pax7 mutant mice during somite formation. Both genes strongly stimulate cell proliferation in various tissues.

Pax8 encodes a protein with a Pax domain but not the typical associated homeodomain.  In vitro translated Pax8, and also the PAX domain from Pax8, bind to specific short sequences found in the promoters of the promoters of thyroglobulin and thyroperoxidase, and can also activate reporters containing this sequence in cotransfection assays (PMID: 1508216).

Pax9 transactivates the murine Bapx1 promoter (bases -5285/+109) following transient transfection in NIH3T3 cells.

Antibody supershift confirmed participation of PBX1 in a retarded complex observed in gele shift studies that were performed to identify 293 cell nuclear proteins the interacted with the PCE. PBX1 enhanced transfection of a Moloney MLV reporter (MLV-LTR-luc) following transient transfection/infection in 293 cells.

Cotransfection of PBX3 and MEIS1 resulted in increased activation of the reporter construct.

PDX1 is a transcription factor. It binds a consensus DNA sequence with high affinity (by selection/amplification analysis with competition EMSA) and transactivates a rat insulin I gene promoter -reporter gene.

Taxa: DNA-Binding: sequence-specific; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Etv4 (alias Pea3) is a transcription cofactor which binds to DNA in complex with other proteins in order to regulate transcription. Etv4 activates reporter expression 24-fold when cotransfected into murine mammary cells with a reporter vector including the mimimal promoter of the murine bax gene. Also, Etv4 interacts directly with an Ets-binding site oligonucleotide in complex with transcription factors ETS-1 and ERM, and interacts indirectly with the murine bax promoter in complex with transcription factor USF-1, as demonstrated by mobility shift assays.
Well-known hormone receptor.

Pitx1 is an homeodomain transcription factor involved in the regulation of the gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptor gene. It is also known to be involved at different stages of developpement such as the formation of hindlimbs or cardiovascular development.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: PITX2 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA by western blotting (with PITX2 antibodies). and interacts with Lex-1 by pull-down assays and western blotting. It transactivates a Lef-1 reporter gene when co-transfected on its own or in concert with Beta-catenin and Lef-1.
Pitx3 is a transcription factors. It binds a DNA site with high affinity (by invitro binding and supershift assays) and transactivates a TH promoter-reporter gene.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: SATB1 and PML interact in a yeast two-hybrid assay and coimmunoprecipitation. EMSA indicates SATB1 and PML interact at matrix attachment regions (MAR). Lucifase reporter assays indicate coexpression of SATB1 and PML enchances each protein's repression activity.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Phox1 (Prrx1) is copurified with DNA-binding transcription factor SPIN. Results confirmed with GST pull-down assays. Transfection assays indicate SPIN/TFII-I cooperates with Phox1 to regulate transcription of the c-fos SRE.

In EMSA, Phox2b specifically binds an oligonucleotide containing the consensus HD-binding core motif of the Phox2a promoter. Phox2b transactivates hPhox2a transcriptional activity in transient cotransfection assays in HeLa cells.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Pou2af1 is a transcription factor binding protein that coactivates octamer-motif containing promoters.  EMSA, immunodepletion, and cotransfection studies show that Pou2af1 interacts with Oct-1 and Oct-2 TFs that bind to the octamer-motif and coactivates the promoter.
Also known as Oct-1. This is a well-known TF.

POU2F2 (OTF-2, OCT2) was cloned from a BJA-B B cell lymphoblastoid cell line expression library using a probe containing multimerized copies of an octamer motif.Recombinant POU2F2, expressed in bacterial lysogens, bound in gel shift assays to a probe derived from the  immunogloblin heavy chain promoter. Methylation interference footprinting demonstrated that POU2F2 interacted with bases contained in the immunogloblin heavy chain promoter (5'-ATGCAAATTA-3').POU2F2 activated promoters containing octamer motifs derived from the immunogloblin heavy chain and H2B promoters following transient transfection in HeLa cells.

Murine Pou3f1 (Oct6) was cloned from embryonal carcinoma cells by low stringency screening with a probe prepared from the murine Oct2 POU domain. The cloned Pou3f1 protein, expressed by transfecting COS cells, binds to oligonucleotides containing the octamer motif (ATTTGCAT) in gel shift assays.DNase I footprinting identified a region of the Mpz (P0) gene promoter that interacted with bacterially expressed rat Pou3f1 (Tst-1). This interaction was confirmed by gel shift studies using an oligonucleotide probe derived from the footprinted region.Pou3f1 repressed trancription from reporter constructs controlled by the Mpz gene promoter (bases -915 to +49) following transient transfection in CV-1 cells.

Pou3f2 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA (by EMSA and supershift assays) and transactivates a Sox2 reporter gene. Futhermore, mutational analysis of the Pou binding sites reduces transactivation of the reporter gene.

Pou3f4 is a POU domain transcription factor which has been demonstrated to be associated when mutated to the X-linked mixed deafness.  Ectopic expression shown to drive expression of the glucagon gene in transgenic mice.
Gel-shift and footprint assays define two Brn3a-binding sites in the TrkA minimal enhancer. Brn3a is required for normal TrkA expression as shown in transgenic mice studies.
DNase footprinting assays and EMSAs show binds to specific sites on the BDNF promoter. Luciferase cotransfection assays indicate Brn-3c can activate the promoter.
Well-known TF.
Ppara is a transcription factor that belongs to the nuclear hormone superfamily and controls the expression of genes involved in hepatic metabolism of glycerol.

Nuclear hormone receptor.I could not find a reference that clearly and unambigously demonstrates DNA binding. However, I know of no nuclear hormone receptor that is not a TF.  So this raises my evaluation just beyond the "candidate" bar.

Prop-1 transactivates a luciferase reporter containing GAL4 DNA binding domain and an adenovirus E1b minimal promoter  in CV-1 cells.Porcine Prop-1 and human Prop-1 binds strongly to the PRDQ9 site in vitro. Both pProp or hProp can transactivate a luciferase reporter gene containing a minimal rat prolactin (rPRL) promoter  fused to PRDQ9 binding sites in 293 cells.

DNase footprinting and gel retardation assays indicate PTF1 (PTF1a) binds the promoter region of the alpha-amylase gene. PTF1 with the PDX1.PBX1b.MEIS2b complex activates the ELA1 minienhancer in transfection assays.

Description: purine rich element binding protein A
Reviewer Commments: PURA was identified as a 24kDa protein in HeLa nucelar extracts that bound preferentially to single-stranded DNA with the consensus sequence 5'-GGNNGAGGGAGARRRR-3' based on gel shift and methylation interference studies.PURA was isolated by Southwestern blotting using a human fetal liver expression library screened with an probe containing the PUR element consensus sequence. Interaction of the cloned PURA protein with the PUR consensus sequence was confirmed by gel shift assays performed using bacterially expressed protein.Pura repressed transcription from a reporter construct regulated by the smooth muscle alpha-actin gene enhancer following transient transcription in COS7 fibroblasts.

Description: purine rich element binding protein B
Reviewer Commments: Gel shift and biotin complexes capture experiments indicate Purb binds the TCE element in the mouse SMA enhancer. Transfection assays indicate Purb is a potent SMA transcriptional repressors in fibroblasts.
Well-known hormone receptor.

Rarg was cloned from a mouse 10.5d embryo library screeened with probes from the human RARA and RARB isoforms. Transient transfection studies show that the cloned protein activated a reporter construct containing three copies of a retinoic acid receptor response element (RARE) following retionic acid treatment in HeLa cells.Rarg binds to a site in the murine RAR-beta2 gene promoter in chromatin immunoprecipitation assays performed using S91 melanoma cells. Transient transfection studies show that Rarg activates a reporter containing 3 copies of a RARE in reponse to treatment with a synthetic retinoid in S91 melanoma cells.

Description: retina and anterior neural fold homeobox
Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Rax binds Pax6 in vitro and coimmunoprecipitation experiments. Rax enhances Pax6-mediated transactivation of a minimal promoter containing consensus Pax6 paired domain-binding sites in cotransfection assays in HeLa cells.
Results of the gel experiments and co-transfection assays suggest that Rax binds a specific element of the mouse arrestin promoter and modulates the gene's transcription.

Rax is a transcription factor.  It binds to DNA in electrophoretic mobility shift assays.  It also transactivates a reporter construct in transient co-transfection experiments in human embryonic kidney cells (293 cells).

Rax is likely a transcription factor given that it binds to the upstream PCE-1 element of the mouse arrestin gene and activates the expression of the both the arrestin and IRBP promoters when cotransfected. The PCE-1 element of the mouse arrestin gene was shown to be bound by protein when incubated with human GST-RX fusion protein. Supershifts using anti-GST antibody further indicated that the GST-RX fusion protein was the factor that was binding to the PCE-1 site. Also, cotransfection of RX with mouse arrestin-lacZ and IRBP-lacZ constructs in 293 cell lines led to increases in reporter activity.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Rax is a TF involved in eye development.  RX shown to bind and activate the PCE-1 promoter element.  There is evidence of protein-protein interaction with Pax6,  but no evidence of binding with Pax6 or DNA in that case.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: pRB is a transcription factor. It interacts with Pax 8 in vitro (by affinity column and band shift assays) and invivo (by ChIp assay) and the Pax8/pRB complex activates a TPO-promoter reporter gene in vitro (by reporter assay and siRNA down regulation of pRB).

Description: recombination signal binding protein for immunoglobulin kappa J region
Reviewer Commments: Authors found that the product of the worm Lag1 gene, like CBF1 and the Drosophila homolog 'suppressor of hairless,' binds specifically to the consensus DNA sequence RTGGGAA. This family of DNA-binding factors that mediate transcriptional activation or repression is designated CSL

Description: recombination signal binding protein for immunoglobulin kappa J region-like
Reviewer Commments: EMSA experiments show RBP-L recognizes the core heptamer sequence GTGGGAA. RBP-L modulates transcriptional activity in luciferase cotransfection assays in COS7 cells.

Rbpsuhl is a transcription factor.  It binds specific sequences of DNA in electromobility shift assays.  It cotransactivates a TP1 promoter reporter construct in cotransfection experiments in the presence of EBNA2, but not in the absence of EBNA2.

Rbpsuhl is likely a transcription factor that interacts with several promoter sequences. Using EMSA, mouse Rbpsuhl was shown to interact with RBP-L binding sites derived from the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) TP1 gene promoter, the mouse HES-1 gene promoter, and the Drosophila E(spl) m8 gene promoter. As well, mouse Rbpsuhl was shown to activate the expression of reporter genes cloned downstream of RBP-L binding sites in cotransfection assays. This data is not as significant given that these promoters were created synthetically, and do not represent actual promoters.

Shows TF activity in conjunction with other proteins.  Shows sequence specific DNA binding,  but requires other protein (EDNA-2) to activate.   Also shown to complex with P48 and activating transcription.

Description: v-rel reticuloendotheliosis viral oncogene homolog A (avian)
Reviewer Commments: relA is the p65 subunit of NFkappaB. It activates a lot of different genes under a lot of different conditions.

Description: avian reticuloendotheliosis viral (v-rel) oncogene related B
Taxa: DNA-Binding: sequence-specific; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: EMSA indicates RELB forms kappa-B-binding heterodimeric complexes with p50 (NFKB1) or p52 (NFKB2). This complex binds DNA at kappa-B-binding motifs and transactivates kappa B-dependent constructs in transfection studies.

Taxa: DNA-Binding: sequence-specific; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: A classic subunit of the NFkappaB family of TFs

EMSA and ChIP assays indicate REST/NRSF is selectively recruited to target genes. RT-PCR analysis of mRNA expression levels in U373 cells shows REST regulates the endogenous expression of several genes.

Description: regulatory factor X, 1 (influences HLA class II expression)
Reviewer Commments: EMSA, DNA affinity pull-down, and ChIP assays show RFX1 binds the promoter region of collagen. RFX1 is found to repress collagen transcription in an in vitro transcription assay in human fibroblasts.

Description: regulatory factor X, 2 (influences HLA class II expression)
Reviewer Commments: RFX2 preferentially binds specific DNA sequences including DRA X and EF-C in EMSA. RFX2 activates the H1t promoter in transient expression assays.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: RFXANK contains a protein-protein interaction region consisting of three ankyrin repeats. Its interaction with RFX5 and RFXAP is essential for binding of the RFX complex to MHC-II promoter sequences both in vivo and in vitro (PMID: 9806546).  However, RFX5 rather than RFXANK appears to contain the DNA-binding domain of this complex (PMID: 1505028).

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: RING1 interacts with multiple Polycomb-group proteins, forming a large multimeric protein complex that is involved in maintaining the transcriptionally repressive state of genes.RING1 is also able to inhibit the RBP-J-mediated transcriptional activation through the formation of a protein complex with KyoT2.No evidence was shown of a direct DNA binding.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: ChIP assays indicate Rnf2 binds the promoter region of Hoxb8. Transfection assays show the de-repression of Hox genes in Rnf2-/- MEFs and ES cells.
Nucelar hormone receptor.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Yeast two-hybrid studies indicate that TRUP (Rpl7) interacts with the full length human thyroid hormone receptor (TR). EMSA demonstrates that TRUP inhibits TR-RXR heterodimers binding to a DR4 element. Transfection assays in Lmtk- cells suggest TRUP inhibits TR- and RAR-mediated transactivation.
Encodes the second largest subunit of RNA polymerase II

RNA POL II is basal transcription factor. Transcription initiation on protein coding genes is mediated by RNApolymerase II and a surprisingly complex array of general initiation factors (TFIIA, -B, -D, E, -F and -H).
Polr2j is a subunit of RNA polymerase II
PC4 is a basal transcription factor. PC4-mediated activated transcription depends both on TAFs in TFIID and on TFIIH by minimal transcription reactions.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; DNA-Binding: sequence-specific
Reviewer Commments: RXRa is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and plays key roles in a variety of physiological phenomenon either as a homodimer or as a heterodimer with a wide range of other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily. Transactivation activity has been confirmed by luceriferase report gene assays using RXRa-specific binding sites, or binding sites specific to RXRa cofactors.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: While it is not clear that it is RXRbeta itself or RAR that binds DNA, the experiments show that it is required for sequence-specific binding of IR0 element and activation as a cofactor for RAR.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding
Reviewer Commments: Ncor1 is a nuclear receptor corepressor. It is first known to bind unliganded nuclear receptors (RAR, TR).Ncor1 was also shown to recruit TF, inactivating them through this interaction.It is part of a protein complex including HDACs and other proteins binding histones. It is thus thought that this complexe acts through the binding to chromatin and deacetylation of histones, maintaining the chromatin in an inactive state.Ncor1 doesn't seem to bind directly to chromatin.

Description: nuclear receptor subfamily 1, group H, member 4
Taxa: DNA-Binding: sequence-specific; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: DNase footprinting and gel shift assays indicate a specific RXR/Nr1h4 binding site within the Std promoter. Induction of the rat Std promoter in HepG2 cells is increased by cotransfection of Nr1h4.

Satb1 was initially characterized as a protein that binds to Matrix Attachment Region sequences (PMID: 1505028) and most of the literature on the gene and its product is in regard to this role.  The DNA-binding specificity is well-studied (PMID: 1505028, PMID: 8114718) and the DNA-binding domain has been mapped (PMID: 8114718) and overlaps approximately with what is apparently a homeodomain that was not evident when the protein was initially characterized.  The initial papers (PMID: 1505028, PMID: 8114718) elaborated upon the structural features of the binding sequence; however, the primary sequence does resemble a classical homeobox.  A SATB1 transgene reduces transcription of a stably-transfected MAR-containing reporter (PMID: 9340009).

ChIP assay indicates Foxp3 binds specific sites within the upstream regions of the IL-2 and IFN{gamma} genes. Transfection experiments show Foxp3 modifies transcription regulation of these genes by modulating histone acetylation/deacetylation.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; DNA-Binding: non-sequence-specific
Reviewer Commments: ChIP assay indicates SIM2/ARNT heterodimer binds EPO enhancer sequences. Western blot and immunofluorescence indicates SIM1 is a nuclear protein. Transcription of EPO is activated by the SIM1/ARNT in luciferase reporter assays in 293T cells.

Taxa: Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Sin3A is a transcription factor. It binds HDAC1/HDAC2 complex by coimmunoprecipitation assays and potentiates the inhibitory function of HDAC1 on the hLHR promoter reporter gene by cotransfection in reporter gene assays.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Myt1 interacts with Sin3B in co-immunoprecipitation and two-hybrid systems. Luciferase cotransfection assays indicate Sin3B interactions with Myt1 confer repression on a heterologous promoter.

Purified Six1 protein binds oligonucleotides containing the MEF3 site from aldolase A (pM) (PMID: 9826681).  Transient transfection experiments in C2C12 cells show that Six1 can transactivate a reporter gene containing MEF3 sites (PMID: 9826681).

Six3 binds the DNA-binding domain of NOR-1 and the EWS domain of EWS/NOR-1 both in vitro and in vivo; the homeodomain of Six3 is required for these interactions. Cotransfection experiments show that Six3 co-activates the transcriptional activity of NOR-1, whereas it co-represses that of EWS/NOR-1 in both C-20/A4 cells and T/C-28 cells.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: The SKIL oncoprotein was found to interact with Smad2 and Smad4 and to repress their abilities to activate transcription through recruitment of the transcriptional corepressor N-CoR.The ski binding site described seems to be a Smad binding site and SKIL would not bind DNA directly but through Smad proteins, inhibiting them by recruiting a nuclear repressor complex.

Description: SWI/SNF related, matrix associated, actin dependent regulator of chromatin, subfamily b, member 1
Reviewer Commments: A ChIP experiment shows that Smarcb1 is recruited to the region of the CSF1 promoter. Luciferase reporter assay in HeLa cells indicates Smarcb1 activates the CSF1 promoter.

Snai1 bound to an oligonucleotide containing a conserved E-box (CAGGTG) in gel shift assays perfromed using nuclear extracts from ATDC5 cells transfected with a plasmid expressing HA-tagged Snai1.Snai1 repressed transcription mediated by the rat Col2a1 gene promoter (bases –977 to +110, pCII-977E) following transient transfection in ATDC5 chondrogenic cells. Transient transfection studies in MDCK and MCA3D cells show that Snai1 represses activity of the mouse E-cadherin promoter sequences (bases -178 to +92) through recruitment of HDAC1/2 and mSin3A.Interaction between Snai1, expressed as a fusion protein with GFP, and the endogenous E-cadherin promoter was demonstrated by chromatin immunopreciptiation studies.
Probably a sequence specific binding protein based on function of ortholog in flies, but no specific lab evidence for DNA binding.  Evidence of repression of Connexin43 supports role as a TF.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Sox1, expressed in reticulocyte lysate, binds to the mouse gamma A-crystallin promoter (bases -67 to -38) in gel shift assays. Sox1 activates the murine gamma F-crystallin gene promoter (bases -1357 to +10) following transient transfection in COS-1 cells.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Sox10 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA (by EMSA assay) and activates an MBP-reporter gene in CG% oligodendrocyte cells.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Good evidence shows sequence specific action of this TF acting on the mouse laminin alpha1 gene.
SOX17 binds specifically to SOX binding sites and is able to potentiate Lama1 enhancer activity.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Yeast one-hybrid screen and EMSA indicates SOX18 binds the mor promoter. Transient transfection and luciferase assays in NMB cells suggest SOX18 activates transcription through the mor promoter.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Sox2 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA by ChIP and supershift EMSA assays and is required for Nanog promoter activity by luciferase reporter gene and RNAi assays.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Sox3, expressed in reticulocyte lysate, binds to a response element in the SF1 promoter (bases -104 to -101) in gel shift assay.Sox3 and Pax6 synergistically activate the murine Pax6 gene LE9 reponse element following transient transfection in cultured SRA01/04 lens epithelial cells.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Sox-5 is part of the HMG family of transcription factors.It binds the HMG specific sites and there is at least one evidence of transactivation of a reporter gene.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Sox6 is an HMG box-containing gene that binds to the DNA sequence 5'-AACAAT-3', with the similar sequence AACAAAG not competing as effectively (PMID: 7567444).  It was also identified in a one-hybrid screen for proteins that bind the PS4A element, specifically requiring an intact central sequence TATTGTC for binding to PS4A by EMSA (PMID: 11504872).  In cotransfection assays it acts as a repressor of Fgf-3 and of reporters containing the PS4A element (PMID: 11504872).

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family
Reviewer Commments: Gel shift assays indicate SOX7 binds a specific site in the Lama1 enhancer. Luciferase assays in F9 cells suggest SOX17 transactivates Lama1 expression through this site.

DBD Classification (Protein Group/Protei: Other Alpha-Helix Group/High Mobility Group (Box) Family

Reviewer Commments: DNA-binding Assay (DBA) and EMSA indicates Sp1 binds the SMA enhancer. Transfection studies reveal the Sp1 binding site of the Cldn19 promoter is crucial for transactivation.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Yeast two-hybrid, GST-pulldown, and coimmunoprecipitation experiments indicate SP100 interacts with ETS1. Luciferase reporter assays suggest SP100 represses the transcriptional activity of ETS1.
SPI-C is a transcription factor. It binds DNA (by EMSA assay) and transactivates an SP6κ light chain promoter-reporter gene.

Description: sterol regulatory element binding transcription factor 1
Reviewer Commments: EMSA demonstrates SREBP (Srebf1) specific binding to the consensus SRE within the CCT promoter. Activation of the CCT promoter was abolished by mutation of this SRE in transfection assays.
SRF is a well-characterized TF inducing the expression of muscle-specific genes.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: SSRP1 is a transcription co-factor. It interacts with SRF (by one-hybrid assays) but does not bind DNA in the complex (by EMSA) and is capable of transactivating (in a SSRP1/SRF complex) a CArG-dependent reporter gene.

Description: signal transducer and activator of transcription 1
Reviewer Commments: Supershift assays indicate STAT 1 binds the specific regions of the PPARγ2 promoter. Stat1 activates reporter genes in transfected HepG2 cells.

Description: signal transducer and activator of transcription 3
Reviewer Commments: Stat3 is purified in DNA-affinity chromatography using the interleukin-6 response element. Stat3 binding to IL-6 RE is confirmed in EMSA. Mouse Stat3 activates transcription in reporter gene assays.

Description: signal transducer and activator of transcription 4
Reviewer Commments: ChIP assays indicates STAT4 is bound to the IL-12Rbeta2 gene enhancer. EMSAs show STAT4 binds specific regions within the promoter of the human perforin gene. Mutation of STAT-binding sequences abolishes activation of the perforin gene promoter in reporter gene assays.

Description: signal transducer and activator of transcription 5A
Reviewer Commments: Stat5 is a well-caracterized TF with specific DNA-binding and transactivation described many times.

Description: signal transducer and activator of transcription 5B
signal transducer and activator of transcription 6
Reviewer Commments: Stat6 was identified by searching an EST database for transcripts homologous to known conserved Stat protein motifs.Gel shift assays performed with IL4-treated human Kit225 T cells showed a single retarded band when incubated with a probe sequence containing the GAS-like element from the human immunoglobulin C-epsilon gene: antibody supershift studies confirmed that Stat6 was contained in retarded complex.Gel shift assays performed with IL4-treated HeLa cells showed a single retarded band when incubated with a probe sequence containing the human IL4R gene promoter IFN-gamma-activated site (GAS) in gel shift assays. Participation of STAT6 in the retarded complex was demonstrated by antibody supershift.Cotransfection studies showed that recombinant STAT6 activated a reporter construct containing containing three copies of the the IL-4R target site following treament of transiently transfected HeLa cells with IL-4. STAT6 transcriptional activity in this system could be reduced by deleting residues in the protein's amino- or carboxy-terminus. A reporter plasmid containing a single copy of the IRF-1 GAS site (IRF-1 GAS-TK-Luc) was activated in STAT6-transfected HeLa cells following treatment with IFN-gamma.

Description: basic helix-loop-helix domain containing, class B2
Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; DNA-Binding: sequence-specific
Reviewer Commments: Dec1 is a basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor involved in regulating the circadian rhythms in mammals. Dec1 and Dec2  repress Clock/Bmal1-induced transactivation of the mouse Per1 promoter through direct protein-protein interactions with Bmal1 and/or competition from E-box elements. The Dec1 binding site, CACGTG, is a class B E-box element, and was identified via a PCR-based binding site selection protocol and EMSA

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Spt5 is part of DSIF,  DRB sensitivity-inducing factor ( DRB being the transcription inhibitor 5,6-dichloro-1-beta-D-ribofuranosylbenzimidazole).DSIF is a dual regulator of transcription that stimulates, or, when cooperating with negative elongation factor (NELF), represses RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) elongation. Spt4 and Spt5 are also thought to be involved in mRNA capping, homologous DNA recombination, and transcription-coupled DNA repair.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: Suv39h1 cooperates with Smad1 (by co-immunoprecipitation) to repress activation of an MCK promoter reporter gene.

Binding site selection studies performed using brachury protein synthesized in reticulocyte lysates identified a 20 base-long palindromic consensus binding site. The consensus site bound to recombinant brachyury protein in gel shift assay. Specific contacts between brachyury and its binding site were demonstrated by methyaltion interference and other footprinting studies. Brachyury activated transcription mediated by a reporter containing two copies of its 20-bp palindromic binding site following transient transfection in HeLa cells. Two pairs of transactivation and repression domains were identiifed by studying fusion proteins containing brachyury deletion mutants linked to the GAL4-DBD in transient transfection assays.

Description: TATA box binding protein (Tbp)-associated factor, RNA polymerase I, A
Reviewer Commments: Is a component of the class I general transcription initiation factor SL1.

Description: TATA box binding protein (Tbp)-associated factor, RNA polymerase I, A
Reviewer Commments: Taf1a is a transcription factor. Taf1A binds DNA (by UV crosslinking) and associates with TBP to form a transcriptionally active TBP-TAF complex by EMSA assays and Western Blot.

Description: TATA box binding protein (Tbp)-associated factor, RNA polymerase I, C
Reviewer Commments: Using immunoaffinity chromatography with anti-TBP, followed by SDS-PAGE analysis, TAF1C is isolated. Antibodies against mTAFI95 (Taf1c) precipitate a protein complex containing TBP.

Description: TAF6 RNA polymerase II, TATA box binding protein (TBP)-associated factor
Reviewer Commments: Taf6 interacts with TAFII250, TAFII31, TAFII20, and TBP in coimmunoprecipitation assays.

Consensus DNA binding sites for a TAL1/E47 heterodimer were identified by cyclic amplification and selection of targets (CASTing) using a FLAG epitope-tagged truncated TAL1 gene product (AA 176 to 331) coexpressed in rabbit reticulocyte lysates with an 85-residue peptide containing the E47 bHLH domain. CASTing experiments were also performed using FLAG epitope-tagged TAL1 construct mixed with Jurkat cell nuclear extracts in order to identify a consensus TAL1 E-box sequence.Binding of the TAL1/E47 heterodimer and endogenous TAL1/E2A heterodimers to oligonucleotides containing the consensus TAL1 E-box sequence (CAGATG) was confirmed by gel shift. Participation of TAL1 in endogenous TAL1/E2A complexes obtained from Jurkat cell nucelar extracts was confirmed by antibody supershift.Cotransfection of TAL1 with E47 resulted in weak activation of a reporter construct containing six copies of the consensus TAL1 E-box (E1bCAT-E6) in C3H10T1/2 cells. In contrast, transfection of E47 without TAL1 strongly induced the reporter construct in the same cell line.

Taxa: Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; DNA-Binding: sequence-specific
Reviewer Commments: All members of the T Box family so far examined bind to the DNA consensus sequence TCACACCT.To identify binding partners for the guanylate kinase domain of CASK (300172), Hsueh et al. (2000) carried out a yeast 2-hybrid screen of brain cDNA libraries, from which TBR1 was isolated. By deletion analysis, the C-terminal region of TBR1 (residues 342 to 681) was found to be necessary and sufficient for association with the guanylate kinase domain of CASK. When coexpressed in COS-7 cells, TBR1 and CASK were readily coprecipitated by antibodies directed against either individual protein. Hsueh et al. (2000) demonstrated that CASK enters the nucleus and binds to a specific DNA sequence (the T element) in a complex with TBR1. CASK acts as a coactivator of TBR1 to induce transcription of T element-containing genes, including reelin, a gene that is essential for cerebrocortical development.

TBX1 is a transcription factor. It binds a core motif (by EMSA and supershifts) and transactivates a synthetic promoter-reporter (which includes a multimer of the motif). It possesses a C-terminal transactivation domain by GAL4 DNA binding domain-XTbx1 fusion activation.

Tbx2 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA by EMSA and binding substitution analysis and transrepresses a T-site reporter gene through its C-terminal repressioin domain as demonstrated by amino acid deletion analysis.
EMSA indicates Tbx3 binds specifically to the Brachyury binding site. Luciferase assays in HEK293 cells show Tbx3 functions as a transcriptional repressor.

In vitro selection procedure identifies a TBX5 consensus-binding site. EMSAs indicate TBX5 binds the mouse Brachyury site and the upstream region of ANF. TBX5 activates reporter expression of ANF in transfection assays.

T7-Tbx6 protein binds the Brachyury consensus sequence in EMSA. Supershift assays indicate binding is Tbx6-specific. Tbx6 binds two putative Tbx6 binding sites in the Dll1 promoter in EMSA. Expression of Dll1 is lost in a Tbx6 mutant.

Taxa: Basal Transcription Factor; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding
Reviewer Commments: TFIIS (Tcea2) is a transcription elogation factor that binds a complex containing RNA polymerase II and the general transcription factors. TFIIS interacts with GRIP1τ in a yeast two-hybrid screen and coimmunoprecipitation assays. Cotransfection assays suggest TFIIS enhances transcriptional activation by GRIP1τ.

Reviewer Commments: The E2F transcription factor family regulates the expression of various cellular promoters, particularly those involved in the cell cycle. MTA2 modulates the enzymatic activity of the histone deacetylase core complex.In 1998, several different groups simultaneously described the protein composition of a macromolecular histone deacetylase complex variously termed the Mi-2 complex, NuRD, NURDor NRD.The Mi-2/NuRD complex unexpectedly provided a physical link between histone deacetylation and ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling.Four different groups reported on the identity of a major Mi-2/NuRD polypeptide of approximately 70–80 kDa. In the human complex designated as NuRD, this protein was reported as the product of the MTA2 gene. In contrast, MTA1 was identified as a component of a strikingly similar human complex termed NURD. In the Mi-2 complex isolated from the amphibian X. laevis, the subunit of similar size was identified as MTA1-like, a gene product now recognized to be the ortholog of mammalian MTA2. Finally, the HDAC1 cII complex was reported to contain MTA2 as well as two ‘truncated forms’ of MTA2.
